channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Benoît Violier, Top French-Swiss Chef, Dies at 44
item.description: Mr. Violier ran a restaurant in Switzerland that was named the world’s best in December. The police said his death seemed to have been a suicide.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Benoît Violier in 2012. The French-Swiss chef was found dead on Sunday at his home in Crissier, near Lausanne, Switzerland.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Shoot the Messenger, Israel
item.description: Lashing out at critics will not resolve an untenable occupation.
item.dc:creator: BAN KI-MOON
item.media:description: A Palestinian man protesting Israeli settlements in the West Bank.

item.title: Israel Approves Prayer Space at Western Wall for Non-Orthodox Jews
item.description: The decision by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s cabinet was seen as a victory for American Jewish leaders and Jewish women who struggled for years for inclusion.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Anat Hoffman, left, of Women of the Wall, said the decision acknowledged “that there is more than one way to be Jewish.”

item.title: Saudi Coalition in Yemen Announces Inquiry Into Bombings
item.description: Responding to criticism of its bombings in Yemen, which rights groups have called war crimes, the Saudi-led military coalition there announced the formation of an investigative committee.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Syria Peace Talks Inch Ahead as Bombings Near Damascus Continue
item.description: Islamic State social media accounts said the group was responsible for the attack, which came as opposing sides of the Syrian conflict were gathered in Geneva for talks.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Residents and pro-government military members at the site of the bombing, near a Shiite shrine south of Damascus.

item.title: U.S. Broadens Fight Against ISIS With Attacks in Afghanistan
item.description: The operations followed President Obama’s decision to expand the authority of American commanders to attack a new branch of the militant group in Afghanistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Iraqi pro-government forces clashed with Islamic State fighters on the outskirts of Ramadi on Sunday.

item.title: New Technologies Give Government Ample Means to Track Suspects, Study Finds
item.description: Fears that encrypted communication will prevent agencies from tracking terrorists are overstated, according to a study that included current and former intelligence officials.
item.category: Berkman Center for Internet and Society
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Kevin hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, and other Justice Department officials have said moves by technology firms to encrypt data have choked off critical ways to monitor suspects.

item.title: Microcephaly, Spotlighted by Zika Virus, Has Long Afflicted and Mystified
item.description: Each year, an estimated 25,000 babies in the United States receive a diagnosis of microcephaly, an abnormally small head, but prognoses are hard to predict.
item.category: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE SAINT LOUIS
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alainah Therrien, who is 15 months old, in the lap of her grandmother, Heather Crossman, with her great grandmother, Rosalie Wherity, in Dennis Port, Mass. Alainah was given a diagnosis of microcephaly before birth.

item.title: Swedish Police Foiled Planned Attack on Immigrants in Stockholm
item.description: When scores of masked men, many of them gang members, descended on the center of Stockholm on Friday to terrorize young migrants, the police were waiting for them.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINA ANDERSON
item.media:credit: Marcus Ericsson/Tt News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in Norrmalmstorg square in Stockholm on Saturday to show their disapproval of an anti-immigration movement.

item.title: Cartoonist Is Arrested as Egypt Cracks Down on Critics
item.description: The arrest of the cartoonist Islam Gawish escalated a crackdown by the government on even moderate forms of dissent.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and AMINA ISMAIL

item.title: Boko Haram Burns Villages in Northeastern Nigeria
item.description: At least 50 people, including children, were killed by gunmen and suicide bombers in a series of raids on villages outside the city of Maiduguri, officials said.
item.dc:creator: SUNDAY ISUWA and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Children stood on Sunday near the rubble of a home that was burned by the Boko Haram group when it attacked Dalori village on the outskirts of Maiduguri in northeastern Nigeria on Sunday. Medics and local residents said at least 50 people, including children, were killed.

item.title: Memo From Argentina: Twisting Inquiry Into Buenos Aires Bombing Takes New Turn
item.description: Argentina’s new government has vowed to get to the bottom of a 1994 attack on a Jewish center that killed 85 people and led to a lasting rift with Iran.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: The aftermath of a suicide bombing at a Jewish center in Buenos Aires in July 1994 that killed 85 people.

item.title: In Iran, New Battle Brews Over Contracts With Foreign Oil Giants
item.description: The battle is threatening to complicate government efforts to attract desperately needed foreign investment, two weeks after the lifting of sanctions.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: How Moon Dust Languished in a Downing Street Cupboard
item.description: The moon dust’s fate was revealed by Britain’s National Archives, which released 178 pages of correspondence on the subject going back 30 years.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS
item.media:description: From left, Commander Neil Armstrong and pilots Michael Collins and Edwin E. “Buzz” Aldrin Jr., were welcomed back to Earth by President Richard M. Nixon.

item.title: Battered by War, Iraq Now Faces Calamity From Dropping Oil Prices
item.description: The country depends on oil for 90 percent of its revenue. Now, it faces crippling budget cuts and increasing difficulty paying government workers.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: The Nahr bin Umar oil field, north of Basra, last month. A collapse in the price of oil, which accounts for more than 90 percent of the Iraqi government’s revenue, points to even tougher times ahead.

item.title: Palestinian Officer Is Killed After Attacking Three Israeli Soldiers
item.description: A Palestinian policeman shot three Israeli soldiers, seriously wounding two, at a West Bank checkpoint.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Israeli security forces gathered around the body of a Palestinian man who was shot dead after an attack on Israelis at a checkpoint in the West Bank.

item.title: Memo From Beijing: President Xi Jinping of China Is All Business in Middle East Visit
item.description: President Xi’s arrival after the lifting of sanctions related to Iran’s nuclear program provided a moment for China to set the stage for future deal-making.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China with King Salman of Saudi Arabia on a visit to Riyadh on Jan. 19.

item.title: Terror Threats Thaw Budgets Across Europe
item.description: Europe is greatly increasing military and security spending on the fight against terrorism, a shift from the austerity mantra that has dominated its policies in recent years.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolling near the Eiffel Tower.

item.title: U.S. and Europe Unlikely to Meet Deadline for Data Transfer Deal
item.description: Officials remain far apart in talks over a new trans-Atlantic pact that international companies must rely on to move digital data between the regions.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: U.S. Challenges China’s Claim of Islands With Maritime Operation
item.description: In an exercise intended to challenge excessive territorial claims by China, a United States vessel entered the disputed waters in the Paracel Islands without giving China notice.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
